webTitle: Full employment is a worthy goal, but it shouldn't come at any cost | Greg Jericho

fields.bodyText: In his address at the National Press Club on Tuesday, the opposition leader Bill Shorten committed a future ALP government to achieving “full employment”. It’s a worthy goal, but should not come at any cost – which is why it is good to see the ALP placing as much focus on underemployment as it is on the overall level of unemployment. The desire for full-employment is a long held commitment, dating in Australia back to the 1945 White Paper on Employment drafted when Ben Chifley was Treasurer, and the Treasury was headed by HC Coombs. The Reserve Bank as one of its legislated aims must “ensure that the monetary and banking policy of the Bank” is directed such that it will best contribute to “the maintenance of full employment in Australia” Crucially it is also required to contribute to “the stability of the currency of Australia”. And this influences the meaning of “full employment”. No one expects full employment to mean 0% unemployment – there will always be some unemployment for various reasons – such as you may have a skill but at that particular time there are not the jobs for that skill. The crucial aspect is the intersection of full employment and stable currency. This intersection is the glorious economic acronym of the “Nairu”, or the non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment. Essentially it is the lowest the unemployment rate at which inflation rate remains steady. The problem is, it’s a bit of a moveable feast. Back in the 1960s, 2% unemployment was almost a given, whereas it is now over 40 years since (in trend terms at least) our unemployment rate has been below 4%: We should remember though that 2% unemployment back in 1966 was a bit easier to achieve than it would be now. For a start, back then only 36% of women were in the labour force – either working or looking for work; now it is 59.5%. How big a difference is that? Were women’s participation rate to be just 36%, it would mean 2.3m fewer women in the labour force. So while looking at past unemployment rates may have us longing for better times, the reality is they were mostly better so long as you were male – at least as far as getting a job goes. That’s not to say fewer people were working back then – in 1974 a peak of 61% of the population over 15 was working – just below the current level of 61.3%: The difference was back then if you weren’t working you were much more likely to be out of the labour force altogether rather than looking for work and thus being technically unemployed. So what level is full-employment now? Shorten in his speech didn’t specify a number, but on ABC’s 7:30 he suggested a target of 5% unemployment. That is a target that sounds about right, if even a little high. Since 1992, after we came out of the recession and once the RBA began targeting inflation of 2%-3%, the point at which inflation begins accelerating is pretty obvious: Once the unemployment rate hit 5% in 2006, the underlying inflation rate stayed above 2.5% and once the unemployment rate went below 4.5% inflation began rising sharply – reaching 4.9% in August 2008, at which point the GFC shoved the inflation genie back in its bottle and unemployment rose to 5.8% in trend terms – the same level it is now. A big reason why inflation rises faster when unemployment gets to a certain level is the lack of capacity. There basically are not enough workers in the right place with the right skills to do all the work. We can see this in the massive surge in skill shortage in 2007 and 2008 when unemployment was low and inflation began to rise: Currently there is much more spare capacity in the labour market, and thus very low pressure on wages. But much of Shorten’s speech talked of increasing capacity – through training and “investments in infrastructure, renewables, defence manufacturing, biotechnology, tourism, food and fibre”. Ideally that would lower the “Nairu”. And indeed given our current very low wages growth, there is some speculation that lower unemployment could be achieved before inflation starts letting rip. The RBA noted in its latest minutes that “the increasingly globalised nature of the labour force” may be a factor in keeping wages growth lower than in the past. If so, that could mean a lower Nairu is possible as wages growth will stay weaker than in the past as unemployment falls. But Shorten was right not to place too much emphasis on the actual unemployment rate. Instead, in both his speech and the 7:30 interview he spent a deal of time talking about underemployed workers. Currently around 8.5% of those in the labour force would like to work more hours. That is actually higher than the 7.9% underemployment rate in the middle of 2009, when unemployment was at the 5.8% level it is now. So we have a case where unemployment is where it was at the peak of the GFC, but where underemployment is higher. The reason is because since then the big jobs growth has been for part-time employment. Since July 2009, time full-time employment has grown by 8.2%, but the adult population has grown by 10.8% so there is now a smaller percentage of adults employed full-time: But the big reason for this is younger workers. In July 2009, 31.8% of people aged 15 to 24 were employed full-time, now it is just 27.9%; whereas the level of full-time workers aged 25 to 64 has actually increased – from 56.1% to 56.5%: It’s why when you look at the rises in underemployment – those aged 15-24 are the big movers: Rather sensibly, the ALP have noted this. On Wednesday night they also released a report on inequality, entitled “Growing Together”. It notes that “on average, it takes young people 4.7 years from leaving full-time education to entering full-time work”. Achieving full-time employment and also reducing underemployment will need to focus on ways to reduce that time. Part-time work is an important part of the labour market, but it has never been a sign of economic health for full-time employment to be growing slower than the population. Aiming for full-employment is a worthy goal, but it is also sensible that the ALP have released the goal in line with its research paper on inequality. Full-employment and a low unemployment rate is no real achievement if it comes through short hours of work, in low paid jobs with little security.

The RBA noted in its latest minutes that “the increasingly globalised nature of the labour force” may be a factor in keeping wages growth lower than in the past. If so, that could mean a lower Nairu is possible as wages growth will stay weaker than in the past as unemployment falls.

But Shorten was right not to place too much emphasis on the actual unemployment rate. Instead, in both his speech and the 7:30 interview he spent a deal of time talking about underemployed workers.

Currently around 8.5% of those in the labour force would like to work more hours. That is actually higher than the 7.9% underemployment rate in the middle of 2009, when unemployment was at the 5.8% level it is now.

So we have a case where unemployment is where it was at the peak of the GFC, but where underemployment is higher.

The reason is because since then the big jobs growth has been for part-time employment. Since July 2009, time full-time employment has grown by 8.2%, but the adult population has grown by 10.8% so there is now a smaller percentage of adults employed full-time:

But the big reason for this is younger workers.

In July 2009, 31.8% of people aged 15 to 24 were employed full-time, now it is just 27.9%; whereas the level of full-time workers aged 25 to 64 has actually increased – from 56.1% to 56.5%:

It’s why when you look at the rises in underemployment – those aged 15-24 are the big movers:

Rather sensibly, the ALP have noted this. On Wednesday night they also released a report on inequality, entitled “Growing Together”. It notes that “on average, it takes young people 4.7 years from leaving full-time education to entering full-time work”.

Achieving full-time employment and also reducing underemployment will need to focus on ways to reduce that time.

Part-time work is an important part of the labour market, but it has never been a sign of economic health for full-time employment to be growing slower than the population.

Aiming for full-employment is a worthy goal, but it is also sensible that the ALP have released the goal in line with its research paper on inequality. Full-employment and a low unemployment rate is no real achievement if it comes through short hours of work, in low paid jobs with little security.
fields.trailText: Bill Shorten is right not to place too much emphasis on the actual unemployment rate - underemployment and job security are crucial issues too
